snippet: The overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi demonstrated for some the futility of democracy, but others faulted the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood for reaching too fast for so many levers of power.
abstract: Islamists are drawing lessons from Egyptian Pres Mohamed Morsi's ouster that could shape political Islam for a generation; for some it demonstrated the futility of democracy in a world dominated by Western powers and their client states; others, acknowledging that the coup accompanied a broad popular backlash, also faulted the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood for reaching too fast for so many levers of power.

byline.original: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and BEN HUBBARD
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Mayy El Sheikh and Kareem Fahim from Cairo; Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates; and Robert F. Worth from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The overthrow of President Mohamed Morsi demonstrated for some the futility of democracy, but others faulted the leaders of the Muslim Brotherhood for reaching too fast for so many levers of power.

headline.main: For Islamists, Dire Lessons on Politics and Power
headline.print_headline: For Islamists, Dire Lessons on Politics and Power

keywords.value: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
